chapters.name: Bentham and the Invention of the Greatest Happiness Principle
topics: Why did Jeremy Bentham (1748-1832) reject natural law, divine command, and social contract theory in favor of a single metric — the greatest happiness for the greatest number — and how did this make him the most radical reformer in British legal history?

How did Bentham's felicific calculus — measuring pleasure by intensity, duration, certainty, propinquity, fecundity, purity, and extent — lay the groundwork for modern cost-benefit analysis, even though no one has ever successfully quantified happiness?

What legal reforms did Bentham's utilitarianism produce — abolishing usury laws, reforming prisons, advocating animal welfare, decriminalizing homosexuality (in 1785, nearly 200 years before Britain did it) — and why were his ideas too radical for his own time?

Why did Bentham request that his body be preserved as an 'auto-icon' — still displayed at University College London — and what does this eccentric final act reveal about a philosopher who believed sentiment should never override rational calculation?

How did Bentham's utilitarianism challenge the British class system — insisting that a peasant's pleasure counts equally with a king's, that tradition and privilege have no moral weight — and why did conservatives see this as more dangerous than revolution?

chapters.name: Mill's Refinement: Higher Pleasures and Liberty
topics: How did John Stuart Mill's childhood — educated by his father James Mill and Bentham himself, reading Greek at three, suffering a mental breakdown at twenty — shape his conviction that Bentham's crude hedonism missed something essential about human happiness?

Why did Mill distinguish between higher and lower pleasures — 'it is better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied' — and how did this hierarchy address the objection that utilitarianism is a 'philosophy of swine'?

How did Mill's 'On Liberty' (1859) argue that individual freedom maximizes aggregate happiness — through the marketplace of ideas, experiments in living, and protection of eccentric minorities — and why is this the most influential defense of free speech ever written?

What did Harriet Taylor contribute to Mill's philosophy — co-authoring 'The Subjection of Women' (1869), shaping his views on liberty and equality — and why has history systematically erased her intellectual partnership?

Where did Mill break from Bentham — on the quality of pleasures, on the importance of justice, on the role of moral rules — and did these refinements save utilitarianism or smuggle in non-utilitarian values through the back door?

chapters.name: Act vs. Rule: The Torture Question
topics: Why does act utilitarianism — judging each individual action by its consequences — lead to morally repugnant conclusions like justifying torture, framing an innocent person, or harvesting one patient's organs to save five?

How does rule utilitarianism — following rules that generally maximize happiness rather than calculating each case — avoid these repugnant conclusions, and does it actually remain utilitarian or secretly become a form of Kantian rule-following?

What did the 'ticking time bomb' scenario reveal after September 11 — when lawyers, politicians, and philosophers debated whether torturing a suspect to locate a bomb was morally permissible — about how easily utilitarian reasoning can justify atrocities?

How did R.M. Hare attempt to resolve the act/rule debate with two-level utilitarianism — everyday moral rules for ordinary decisions, act-utilitarian calculation for extraordinary cases — and why did critics call this 'the worst of both worlds'?

Name three real-world cases where act-utilitarian reasoning produced outcomes that most people consider monstrous — the Tuskegee syphilis experiment, forced sterilization programs, nuclear targeting of civilians — and what do these cases reveal about utilitarianism's blind spots?

chapters.name: The Trolley Problem and Moral Intuitions
topics: Why did Philippa Foot's trolley problem (1967) — divert a trolley to kill one person instead of five — become the most famous thought experiment in modern philosophy, and what does the near-universal willingness to pull the switch reveal about human moral intuitions?

Why do most people refuse to push the fat man off the bridge to stop the trolley — even though the utilitarian calculus is identical to pulling the switch — and what does this inconsistency reveal about the difference between impersonal and personal harm?

How did Joshua Greene's fMRI studies show that trolley dilemmas activate different brain regions — impersonal dilemmas engage rational calculation, personal dilemmas trigger emotional responses — and does neuroscience support or undermine utilitarian ethics?

How have self-driving car algorithms turned the trolley problem from a classroom exercise into an engineering decision — should a car swerve to kill one pedestrian rather than five? — and why did MIT's Moral Machine experiment reveal massive cultural variation in moral intuitions?

What did Bernard Williams mean when he called utilitarianism's demand to always maximize happiness an attack on 'integrity' — that it requires you to abandon your deepest commitments whenever the numbers dictate — and is this a fatal objection or exactly the point?

chapters.name: Singer, Preference Utilitarianism, and Animal Liberation
topics: How did Peter Singer's 'Animal Liberation' (1975) extend utilitarian logic to non-human animals — arguing that the capacity to suffer, not species membership, determines moral status — and why did he call ignoring animal suffering 'speciesism,' comparable to racism or sexism?

What is preference utilitarianism — measuring welfare by the satisfaction of preferences rather than the subjective experience of pleasure — and how did this version address the problem of comparing different kinds of happiness across different beings?

Why did Singer argue that affluent people who don't donate to famine relief are morally comparable to someone who walks past a drowning child — and how did the 'shallow pond' thought experiment challenge the distinction between killing and letting die?

How did Singer's arguments about severely disabled infants — that some cases of infanticide might be morally permissible if the infant cannot have preferences — provoke death threats, cancelled lectures, and the accusation that utilitarianism leads inevitably to eugenics?

What separates Singer's utilitarianism from Bentham's — the shift from hedonic states to preference satisfaction, the greater attention to animal welfare, the global scope of moral obligation — and has Singer pushed utilitarianism to its logical conclusion or past its breaking point?

chapters.name: Utilitarianism in Public Policy and Economics
topics: How did cost-benefit analysis — a direct descendant of Bentham's felicific calculus — become the standard tool for evaluating government regulation, and what happens when regulators assign dollar values to human lives ($7.4 million per life in the US as of 2024)?

What are QALYs (quality-adjusted life years) — the utilitarian metric used by Britain's NICE and other health agencies to decide which treatments to fund — and why did the decision to value one QALY at £20,000-£30,000 effectively put a price on human life?

How did the COVID-19 pandemic force explicitly utilitarian trade-offs — lockdowns that saved lives but destroyed livelihoods, ventilator triage protocols, vaccine distribution priorities — and why did different countries reach radically different conclusions using the same utilitarian framework?

Why did economists from Pigou to Nordhaus use utilitarian discount rates to argue that future generations' welfare counts less than present welfare — effectively saying a life in 2100 is worth less than a life today — and how does this calculation shape climate change policy?

How did the 'value of a statistical life' methodology — derived from workers' willingness to accept risk for higher wages — embed utilitarian reasoning into workplace safety, environmental regulation, and transportation policy without most citizens knowing it?

chapters.name: Effective Altruism: Utilitarianism Goes Viral
topics: How did the effective altruism movement — founded by philosophers William MacAskill and Toby Ord around 2011 — turn utilitarian calculation into a social movement, pledging billions in donations and recruiting thousands of young people to 'do the most good'?

Why did effective altruists prioritize deworming children in Kenya over building schools in their own communities — because the cost-per-DALY-averted was dramatically lower — and what does this prioritization reveal about the tension between utilitarian optimization and common moral intuitions?

How did the Sam Bankman-Fried scandal (2022) — an effective altruist who allegedly defrauded FTX customers to fund charitable giving — expose the movement's vulnerability to 'earning to give' logic taken to criminal extremes?

Why do effective altruists focused on 'longtermism' — the idea that reducing existential risk to future trillions of humans is the most important cause — face criticism for diverting resources from present suffering toward speculative future scenarios?

What did the effective altruism movement get right — demanding evidence for charitable claims, exposing ineffective charities, normalizing large-scale giving — and what did it get wrong about treating moral life as an optimization problem?

chapters.name: Critics and Alternatives: What Utilitarianism Cannot See
topics: How did John Rawls challenge utilitarianism in 'A Theory of Justice' (1971) — arguing that no rational person behind a 'veil of ignorance' would choose a society that maximizes aggregate happiness at the expense of the worst-off — and why did this shift political philosophy away from utilitarian foundations?

Why did Amartya Sen argue that utilitarianism's focus on subjective welfare ignores 'capabilities' — that a person adapted to oppression might report high satisfaction while lacking real freedom — and how did this critique reshape international development policy?

What did Robert Nozick's 'experience machine' thought experiment prove — that most people would refuse to plug into a machine providing permanent bliss, suggesting happiness is not the only thing humans value — and does this refute hedonistic utilitarianism?

How do feminist critics (including Virginia Held and Nel Noddings) argue that utilitarianism's impartial, calculating framework ignores relationships, care, and the particular obligations we owe to specific people — and can a theory that treats everyone's suffering as interchangeable capture what matters in a parent-child bond?

Why has utilitarianism survived 250 years of devastating criticism — from Williams, Rawls, Nozick, Sen, and feminist ethics — remaining the default framework for policy analysis, and what does its persistence reveal about the poverty of alternatives?
